Encinitas, CA 7/5/2012 Definitely the best Mexican food in Encinitas.
LOVED me the carnitas taco, enchilada, and refried beans. Four stars to the carne asada plate. Pass on the tamale.
It's slightly nicer on the inside than Juanitas or Filibertos, but not quite date-night worthy... an order at the front, eat in plastic chairs type of place. It seemed to be slightly more expensive than Encinitas comparables, but the increase in quality far outweighs the increase in price.
The Nopalito market looks like a great place to get meats and other Mexican food necessities, and bonus points for being (or at least looking) cleaner than El Torito Market on the 101.
This shopping center could really round itself out by adding a down-to-earth, blue-collar Mexican bar. Yes please.

Encinitas, CA 2/27/2012 Every New Year's Eve my BF and I make a list of 12 must try restaurants to hit by year's end. Thank goodness El Nopalito made the list.
C rating rumors had me a little sketched out so was thrilled to be welcomed by an A at the door.
The employee behind the counter oozed with friendliness and helpful recomendations. We're thinking he had to be the owner's son. If not, he deserves a big fat raise.
I asked him what the best meat dish they had was and he steered me to the Carne Asada plate which came with rice, beans, chips and 3 tortillas for $9.51! The meat was seasoned to sheer perfection and such a large portion that it was 3 separate meals for me - one heavy dinner and 2 light lunches. My vegetarian boyfriend opted for the cheese enchildadas and was also very pleased.
Recognizing El Nopalito was known for their salsa, we quizzed the employee about his favorite choice. He stopped what he was doing, told the next guest in line he'd be right back to take their order and then proceeded to walk us to the salsa bar to direct us to the roasted salsa. AMAZING and unique! He then came back with a large basket of complimentary chips for us to enjoy while we waited for our meal.
While this place has zero ambiance, it offers a great value on authentic, flavorful Mexican food and is definitely worth a place on your list!

Cardiff-by-the-Sea, CA 1/30/2011 I love El Nap. El Nap has, hands down, the best Carne Asada I have ever tasted! And, when you get it uncooked to bring home for w BBQ it like $4 a pound, which works out great when trying to feed a crowd and not break the bank. The Carnitas is also very good.
My favorite part about El Nap has to be the freshness of everything. If you've only been to the restaurant and never been over to the store, you gotta go and check out the monster tortilla making machine. A good tortilla can seriously make or break a burrito for me and El Nap knows what they are doing when it comes to tortillas. The chips are always fresh and never stale also.
The salsa selection, also extremely fresh, is amazing. You have to try the Roasted Red! My parents live in Seattle and are constantly trying to get me to ship it up to them. I also really like the Salsa Fresca and the Guacamole is delicious. If you've ever had ceviche, and enjoyed it, you gotta try it here. Again, it's super fresh and the seafood mix is great.
I also really like that El Nap isn't afraid to serve some truly authentic, and often not offered, selections. The Lengua, cow's tongue, is amazing and I really like the tripe in the Menudo.
I've never been disappointed by El Nap and plan to continue going there as often as possible.

San Clemente, CA 8/28/2010 I like getting off Santa Fe Drive to go to the gas station there. I've seen this little restaurant hanging out near the 7-11 for years. Usually, though, I'm by that way late in the evening. So late I don't think they were even open.
Finally, today, I got my chance and boy I'm glad I did. Apparently it's a popular spot as there were a number of people enjoying dinner and a number of people waiting in line to get to order dinner. Mixed crowd, mixed ethnicities -- definitely a good sign.
I ordered a simple Vegetarian Burrito for $5.30 I waited a bit over 5 minutes and while I waited I got some salsa - they had at least 5 different kinds and I tried to. Okay, one would probably be better defined as a pico de gallo and the other was some sort of chipolte salsa. While I waited I got to watch an American Football game on TV and browse their jukebox machine - filled mostly with Mexican and Spanish music. I wasn't going to eat there so I didn't pop in $1 to enjoy 3 songs of my choosing.
Eventually my food came and the burrito was delicious and BIG. The burrito appeared to contain refried beans, rice, cheese, pico de gallo, and guacamole. I was also stoked to get a small side of chunky, thick chips. Both were SO satisfying. I didn't really dig the pico de gallo as it was a little to watery for me - but that might have been my own fault when digging it up in the first place. And, I'm not much of a chipolte fan, but if you are, it had some nice heat. I was ready to pop by the time I had a 1/4 of a burrito left and a number of chips left -- but they were so good I ate the rest of the burrito.
Can't wait to try 'em again and satisfying my urge for an awesome veggie burrito and just as awesome chips.

Carlsbad, CA 5/19/2009 For the uninitiated, do not confuse the two (2) El Noplitos. While affiliated, they are not litterally attached as each are in their own buildings that are next to each other. One is the local Mexican market; the other is the restaurant.
I've always embraced El Nopalito, the restaurant, and then quietly, they taco rolled out of my lunch rotation. I'd drive by and tell myself, Oh yeah! I need to go back even though - I went to other places a block away. Since the plaza's remodeling, I've escaped work like others to have lunch in a local joint and watch ESPN during lunch. HA.
My preferred taco of choice (wait for it....) - carnitas. I prefer my carnitas to not be stringy or shredded or dry - akin to a piece of forgotten turkey meat texturely (is that a word?). EN's carnitas are everything else and beyond what I don't like.
On the other hand, El Nopalito is known for their tamales - cheese, chicken, pork, or beef. They do brisk business during Christmas - which I still don't understand the connection of tamales and Christmas - short of googgling. Regardless I am not averse to their tamales at all either!
Don't dismiss El Nopalito because of its obvious location in a small corner stripmall in the northeast corner of I-5 and Santa Fe Avenue. It's not a sexy local shopping venue, but it has everything for the local neighborhood.
